A bug has been found in Cantera, but it occurs only for cases that  
are "obscure", so hopefully not many are affected.

Under some conditions, the reverse rate of progress of a reaction  
will be computed incorrectly. This ONLY occurs if ALL of the  
following are true:

1. the reaction is reversible
2. the reaction has four or more product molecules
3. the stoichiometric coefficient for some product species is greater  
than one.

If any of these conditions is NOT true (rxns with three or fewer  
product molecules, or ones in which all product molecules are  
different species) WILL NOT have this problem. And of course since it  
ONLY affects reverse rates of progress, not forward ones,  
irreversible reactions do not have this problem.

The essence of the problem is that if the above conditions are met,  
then the concentration products for the reverse rate in the law of  
mass action are computed with exponents of 1.0, rather than the  
product stoichiometric coefficients.  The reactant concentration  
products and equilibrium constants are always computed correctly.  
This affects both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions.

In general, this will only impact simulations with global reactions  
modeled as reversible, since hardly any elementary reactions have  
four or more products.
A reaction for which this problem occurs is the global reforming  
reaction

CH4 + H2O <=> CO + 3 H2

since it has 4 product molecules, and the H2 stoichiometric  
coefficient is greater than 1.  It may be easily verified that at  
equilibrium, the reverse rate does not equal the forward rate, as it  
must.


Fix
=====

If you want to do it yourself, edit file Cantera/src/ 
ReactionStoichMgr.cpp, and change line 116 to read:

m_revproducts->add(rxn, r.products, r.pstoich, r.pstoich);

instead of:

m_revproducts->add(rxn, r.products, m_dummy, r.pstoich);



The CVS repository has been updated with this fix.

Thanks to Andrew Colclasure at Colorado School of Mines for pointing  
out the problem.

Dave
